user.biography: This is the official Instagram for Grand Teton National Park. Use #MyGrandTeton for a chance to be featured. Top 10 tips for visiting the park:

node.text:
Grand Teton National Park has experienced many wonderful things this decade, thanks for spending the past 10 years with us! We cannot wait to see what the next decade brings.
#mygrandteton #findyourpark #encuentratuparque

node.title: Grand Teton National Park: A Look Over the Past Decade

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on July 31, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, body of water and nature.

node.text:
It's World Ranger Day! 

Today we celebrate the rangers - both past and present - whose hard work helps keep Grand Teton grand! Rangers fill many necessary roles within the park: connecting with and assisting visitors; studying and protecting natural resources; responding to emergencies; keeping facilities clean and in good condition; educating through programs, media, and conversation; and so much more. 

Grand Teton is proud to have a dedicated team representing the park. We tip our flat hats to you!

#WorldRangerDay #MyGrandTeton 

NPS Photos/J. Bonney

node.text:
Legend has it, summer is over once the fireweed flower blooms to the top of its stalk.

Luckily for us, it looks like we still have some summer days left!

If you're still planning an upcoming trip to Grand Teton National Park, don't forget to check out our park's website to help you #PlanLikeAParkRanger. 

Link in bio!

Photo courtesy of M. Duff .

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on July 29, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, nature and tree.

node.text:
It’s the timeeeee of the seeeeason…..For moni-toring!

If you've been in the area, you might have noticed more Grand Teton staff out in the sagebrush steppe lately. That’s because it is the time of year when surveys occur in restored and undisturbed communities around the park. Recording the presence and amount of hundreds of species allows the vegetation branch to track change over time and understand how to approach future management. This is work fit for those who love attention to detail and an office made of blue skies and mountain backdrops!

Without this long-term monitoring, the park would miss out on important information such as changes in biodiversity and new invasions. It is also critical to the assessment of restoration success.

#secretsofthesage #restoration #ecology #nationalparkscience 

Photo courtesy of S. Wessel

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on July 29, 2021. May be an image of nature and mountain.

node.text:
Traveling through Grand Teton National Park you will have a view of the Teton Range. This beautiful landscape often overshadows some of the smaller sites within the park. One of these is the J. P. Cunningham Cabin. 

John and Margaret Cunningham staked a claim for the Bar Flying U Ranch in the 1880s. John built his cabin in the Appalachian style in 1888. The cabin remained as their main house until 1895. 

The Bar Flying U Ranch has a rich and interesting history beyond the fact that it provides a window to the past of early life in the Jackson Hole Valley.

John and Margaret Cunningham ran a profitable ranch until the end of World War I, changing because of drought and falling cattle prices. The Cunningham's and neighbor Josian David “Si” Ferrin created a petition that was then signed by 97 valley ranchers. This petition proposed a buyout of ranches to create a national recreation area. 

The Cunningham Cabin is north of the Snake River Overlook on Highway 191, near the eastern boundary of the park. 

#FindYourPark #MyGrandTeton 

Photo Courtesy of/ BK Appleby

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on July 29, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Can you see through this little critters camouflage?

It's time for a #PikaPost! Pikas (Ochotona princeps) are small mammals that live in rocky spaces at higher elevations! They resemble their closest relative, which is the bunny, except for their rounded ears. The sandy and brownish color of their fur acts as a camouflage in their rocky homes to protect them from predators. 

Pikas are very hardy animals and are native to alpine terrain. These cooler temperatures are what they thrive in as anything hotter than 78 degrees Fahrenheit is too much heat for them to survive! Pikas are also herbivores and sustain themselves on grasses, weeds, and different plants near their rocky dens which they will dry out in the sun before dragging into their dens for the cold winter. 

What are some animals that use camouflage to blend into their surroundings where you're from?

Image caption: A small brown and tan colored Pika nibbles on a green plant on top of a boulder field. 

#FindYourPark #MyGrandTeton 

Photo courtesy of M. Yang

node.accessibility_caption: Alt Text: A bison walks through a grassy field with the Teton range towering behind it

node.text:
What did the bison say when his son crossed the road?
.
.
.
.
"BI-SON!"

…But hopefully not for good. 

An animal gets hit by a car almost every day in Grand Teton National Park during the summer. Slow down, stay attentive, and watch for animals crossing the road, especially at night. You could save a life!

 #MyGrandTeton #TetonSafe 

Photo courtesy of S. Textor

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on July 28, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Welcome to #WildflowerWednesday!

Each Wednesday we will be sharing wildflowers from Grand Teton National Park. In turn you may have some of your own favorite wildflower/s where you live, or wildflowers you have discovered when visiting national parks. Post your favorite wildflower photos here!

This week's Wednesday Wildflower is Fireweed (Epilobium angustifolium). Fireweed can be found throughout Grand Teton. It earned its name because this plant is the first colonizer in the soil after forest fires.

Fireweed grows to be about 4 feet tall and has stunning magenta blooms. It thrives in cooler locations and prefers full sun and moist soil.  It attracts butterflies, hummingbirds, and bees.

#findyourpark #MyGrandTeton #Pollinators #WildflowerWednesday 

Photo Courtesy of SM Appleby

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on July 28, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Where can I find wildlife?!

Good question. It’s not so much about where.... but when!

Most of our larger mammals, like moose and bears, are crepuscular. This means they are more active at dawn and dusk. Getting up early or staying out late will increase your chances of viewing wildlife here in the park.

You can see wildlife ANYWHERE throughout the park. However, certain animals tend to hang out in particular habitats. For example, moose prefer wetland environments and pronghorn like the valley floor.

Have you had any luck finding wildlife in our park?

Photo courtesy of M. Duff

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on July 27, 2021. May be an image of body of water and nature.

node.text:
Our fish are in hot water.

It is challenging for fish like the Snake River Fine Spotted Cutthroat Trout to survive during these hot temperatures. Handling fish during the heat of the day adds more stress that could be fatal to the fish.

🕑 Check the time. It is recommended that anglers cease fishing at 2 p.m. when water temperatures approach or exceed 68 degrees F.
🌊 Keep fish wet. Avoid taking photos or handling outside of the water.
🌡️ Carry a thermometer. Know the temperature of the water and avoid fishing during high water temperatures.

For more information go to www.nps.gov/grte/planyourvisit/fish

Photo courtesy of M. Canetta

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on July 27, 2021. May be an image of body of water and nature.

Photo by Grand Teton National Park on July 27, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'HELP OUR NATIVE TROUT OUR FISH ARE IN HOT WATER High water temperatures are more stressful for fish in rivers and streams. Know what temperature the water is before you fish. STOP FISHING at 68 F 60°F 65°F High Temperatures 45°F Optimal Temperatures Fish on, these temps are prime fishingcoitions. Often, these high water temperatures occur when the highs are forecasted to reach 85° Warm Temperatures Use heavier line and release the fish quickly after catching it. Fish may be prone to stress. Stress caused by catch and release can be fatal to fish'.
Photo by Grand Teton National Park on July 27, 2021. May be an image of lake, sky and nature.

node.text:
Family hiking in Grand Teton National Park!

Grand Teton National Park is known worldwide for their breadth of hiking trails. These range from strenuous, to easy. While the strenuous trails are often discussed, there are still family friendly trails. 

These family friendly trails are perfect for young and upcoming hikers. They offer some splendid views and opportunities to see the park's abundant wildlife. 

When taking our youngest visitors hiking be sure to hydrate them more often than an adult needs. Recognizing when younger hikers meet their limit for the day is sooner than older hikers. Always understand that younger hikers should be enjoying the hike. If they are not, it will be harder to convince them to go hiking again. 

Encourage the young hikers to pause and investigate the smaller wonders of the park as observers. They are our future stewards of the park's resources.

For more information on the Teton's hiking opportunities; 
https://www.nps.gov/grte/planyourvisit/hike.htm

Photo Courtesy/ SM Appleby

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on July 26, 2021. May be an image of nature, tree and mountain.

node.text:
The mountains aren't disappearing - there's smoke in the air!

Smoke sensitive individuals and those with sensitive airways should take extra precautions when recreating outdoors. 

Learn more about current air quality at https://fire.airnow.gov.

#PlanLikeAParkRanger #TetonSafe 

NPS Photo/J. Bonney

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Grand Teton National Park on July 26, 2021. May be an image of animal and nature.

node.text:
"Please don't take selfies with the fluffy cows!" The T shirt read.

Bison can move quickly when annoyed and do serious damage with those horns.  Stay at least 25 yards from bison and other animals, and 100 yards from bears and wolves.

But did you know these animals are the descendants of bison who were part of a wildlife park near Oxbow Bend? The wildlife park started in 1948. From it's beginning it drew controversy.

The wildlife park was soon disbanded. This was not before 15 bison escaped into the wild. The Teton's current 700+ bison herd are the descendants of those rebellious 15.

#MyGrandTeton

Contribution and Photo courtesy of/ L. Wilbanks
Taken with zoom lens
